content: I don't like the names Matrix.fromRows and Matrix.fromColumns for stacking two matrices vertically and horizontally, respectively. What do you think the names should be?

/poll Your preferences?
Matrix.fromRows and Matrix.fromColumns (status quo)
Matrix.fromRows and Matrix.fromCols
Matrix.stackVertically and Matrix.stackHorizontally
Matrix.vertically and Matrix.horizontally
(I don't much like introducing the new words "vertically" and "horizontally" when everything else refers to rows and columns.)
We should be consistent with docs#Matrix.updateColumn on the Col vs Column thing, but renaming/deprecating that would be fine
For some comparison, numpy has np.row_stack, but it was deprecated in favor of np.vstack

Eric Wieser said:

We should be consistent with docs#Matrix.updateColumn on the Col vs Column thing, but renaming/deprecating that would be fine

There is more...
docs#Matrix.row
docs#Matrix.col
Yes, hence saying it's fine to decide on col instead of column; we should just apply the change globally if we're renaming things

Let me just repeat that I prefer Kim's suggestion over mine.
When you write Matrix.fromRows it sounds like the arguments are the rows of the resulting matrix, which is inaccurate.
When you write appendRows it suggests that the second argument contains several rows to be appended.
Even better, if we prefix it Matrix.appendRows as usual, we can use the dot notation with a meaningful semantics.
Yes but fromBlocks captures its semantics whereäs fromRows doesn't.
Given the consensus on Matrix.fromCols I made a PR: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19825
Martin Dvořák has marked this topic as resolved.
